elements.title: Income Anchor Typography: Large Number as Visual Anchor
elements.problem: Kahneman's anchoring research demonstrates that the first number presented becomes the reference point for all subsequent judgments. Visually, anchoring is amplified by typographic weight: larger, bolder numbers are perceived as more important and become stronger anchors. When per-night rates are displayed in the same typographic weight as monthly totals, the host's eye has no visual hierarchy to guide it toward the number that matters most ($5,000/month total vs. $85/night). The current pricing typography likely treats all numbers with equal visual weight, losing the opportunity to use typographic scale as an anchoring mechanism. Tammy needs to see one number — the paired-tenant monthly total — that dominates the visual field and becomes her anchor.
elements.solution: Apply a dramatic typographic scale differential between the primary income anchor and secondary price details. The monthly total should be displayed at 36px (--text-4xl) in Inter Bold 700, using --primary-purple (#31135D) to signal authority and brand alignment. Secondary details (per-night rate, per-tenant breakdown) should use 14px (--text-base) in --text-gray (#6b7280). The visual scale ratio should be at least 2.5:1 (36px/14px) to create an unmistakable visual hierarchy. The primary number should have additional spacing above and below (--spacing-3xl) to create breathing room that draws the eye. This is visual anchoring: the largest, boldest, most prominent number on any pricing screen becomes the anchor that the host's System 1 latches onto.

evidence.quote: I can look to people all day long at 5,000 a month.
evidence.insight: The $5,000 figure dominates her financial thinking. The visual presentation of Split Lease income must dominate the pricing screen with equal force.

evidence.quote: The anchoring effect was 55%... Similar values have been observed in numerous other problems.
evidence.insight: Anchoring effects are consistently strong (30-55%). Visual prominence amplifies anchoring because System 1 processes visual scale before reading content. A large number is perceived as a large amount.
The design system already has a 36px hero heading size. Using it for income numbers creates consistency with the existing typographic scale while applying it to a new context (financial anchoring).

typography: Inter Bold 700 at 36px (--text-4xl) for primary income number
Inter Medium 500 at 14px (--text-base) for secondary details
DM Sans Semibold 600 at 12px (--text-sm) for labels above the number ('Estimated Monthly Income')
spacing: --spacing-3xl (28px) above and below primary income number
--spacing-lg (16px) between primary number and secondary detail section
new_tokens_needed: --text-income-hero: 36px — same as --text-4xl but semantically distinct for income display contexts

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: #31135D on #ffffff = 13.6:1 (AAA compliant). #31135D on rgb(252,250,255) = ~13:1 (AAA compliant). #6b7280 on #ffffff = 4.6:1 (AA compliant for regular text).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The primary income number must be the largest number on any screen where it appears. No other element — not the listing title, not the property count, not the nightly rate — should exceed its visual weight. This is the visual implementation of Kahneman's 'first number becomes the anchor.'
elements.brand_alignment: The purple palette conveys authority and sophistication. Using --primary-purple for income numbers aligns financial data with brand trust. The contrast between the large purple income number and the gray detail text creates the 'clean, modern' aesthetic described in the Style Guide while serving a cognitive function (anchoring).

elements.title: Trust Signal Card: Purple-Border Differentiation Markers
elements.problem: Tammy's Airbnb availability cascade means that visual similarity to Airbnb triggers automatic categorization as 'another Airbnb.' Kahneman's priming research shows that visual elements activate associative networks: if the platform looks like Airbnb, it is Airbnb in System 1's assessment. The current visual language may use standard marketplace patterns (card grids, star ratings, review counts) that are visually interchangeable with Airbnb's interface. The platform needs a distinctive visual language that immediately signals 'this is a different kind of platform' — one that serves hosts, not guests. The visual signal must be so prominent that it registers in the first 2 seconds before any text is read.
elements.solution: Create a distinctive 'Host Control Signal' visual pattern using a left-border accent on trust-related cards and sections. Each trust commitment (host policy control, income guarantee, no unilateral cancellation) should appear in a card with a 3px left border in --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)). The card background should be --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) — the purple-tinted off-white that creates a subtle but distinctive warm feel unlike Airbnb's neutral white. Icons should use Feather icons at --icon-md (24px) in --primary-purple. This visual pattern — purple left-border card on purple-tinted background — becomes the signature element that the host associates with 'this platform serves me.' It is visually distinct from Airbnb's rounded white cards with shadow elevation.

evidence.quote: I really can't stand Airbnb... I prefer VRBO... they kind of let you set the policy.
evidence.insight: Differentiation from Airbnb is not just informational but emotional. The visual language must create a feeling of 'this is different' before any copy is read.

evidence.quote: System 1 tries its best to construct a world in which the anchor is the true number.
evidence.insight: Visual anchoring works like numerical anchoring: the first visual impression constructs a world. If the visual impression says 'professional host tool,' subsequent information is processed through that lens.
The protocol surface background (#F7F2FA) provides a distinctive warm-purple tint that differentiates from Airbnb's cool neutral backgrounds. This token already exists and can be leveraged.

typography: Inter Semibold 600 at 16px (--text-md) for trust commitment headline
Inter Regular 400 at 14px (--text-base) for supporting description
new_tokens_needed: --border-trust-accent: 3px solid rgb(109, 49, 194) — semantic border token for trust signal cards

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: #1a1a1a on #F7F2FA = ~14:1 (AAA compliant). #374151 on #F7F2FA = ~7.5:1 (AAA compliant). rgb(109, 49, 194) left border is decorative, no contrast requirement.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Trust signal cards must be visually distinct from standard content cards. The left-border + purple-tinted background combination creates a visual 'family' of trust elements that the host learns to recognize. Standard content cards use --bg-white with --border-color border. Trust cards use --protocol-surface with --secondary-purple left border. This visual contrast makes trust signals scannable without reading.
elements.brand_alignment: The left-border accent pattern conveys precision and intentionality. It avoids the rounded, shadow-heavy card patterns associated with consumer marketplaces (Airbnb) and instead signals a professional tool. The purple-tinted background creates warmth within the brand palette, following the Style Guide's recommendation to add warmth to the otherwise cool purple system.

elements.title: Portfolio Grid: Multi-Property Visual Overview at Scale
elements.problem: Tammy manages 9 NYC units plus Bay Area properties. A list or single-card view that shows one property at a time forces sequential scanning: she must scroll through 9+ items to assess her portfolio. Kahneman's availability heuristic predicts that the property most recently viewed (the one at top of the list or the one she scrolled past last) will dominate her assessment of overall platform performance. A single underperforming property at the top of the list makes the entire platform feel like it is underperforming. Professional hosts think in portfolios; the visual pattern must support portfolio-level assessment in a single view.
elements.solution: Design a compact portfolio grid that shows all properties simultaneously, with visual density appropriate for professional hosts. Each unit should be a compact card (~180px width) showing: unit name, monthly income (prominently), occupancy percentage as a visual bar, and a status indicator (green dot for active, amber for below target, gray for vacant). The grid should accommodate up to 14 units without scrolling on a 1280px desktop viewport. Use --bg-light (#f9fafb) as the grid background, with individual unit cards in --bg-white with --shadow-sm. Income numbers in each card should use Inter Semibold 600 at 18px (--text-lg) in --primary-purple — smaller than the hero income number but still prominent enough to enable quick portfolio scanning. The total portfolio income should appear above the grid as a summary row using the hero typography from looks-001.

evidence.quote: I have like 13, 14 [units]... I have nine units in New York. I have two brownstones and then I have units that I rent in the bay area.
evidence.insight: She conceptualizes her holdings as a portfolio with geographic groupings. The grid should support visual grouping (NYC group, Bay Area group) without requiring separate pages.

evidence.quote: A salient event that attracts your attention will be easily retrieved from memory... You are therefore likely to exaggerate the frequency.
evidence.insight: A portfolio grid where all units are visible simultaneously prevents any single unit from dominating attention. The grid view distributes attention across the portfolio, reducing availability bias from any one property.

evidence.quote: --container-lg: 1280px for wide content. --gap-lg: 1rem for comfortable gaps.
evidence.insight: The design system supports a wide container that can accommodate a multi-column grid. Using 1rem gaps keeps the grid compact enough for 14 units while maintaining visual breathing room.

typography: Inter Semibold 600 at 18px (--text-lg) for per-unit income
Inter Medium 500 at 12px (--text-sm) for unit name and metadata
Inter Bold 700 at 28px (--text-2xl) for portfolio total in summary row
new_tokens_needed: --card-portfolio-min-width: 180px — minimum card width for portfolio grid items
--grid-portfolio-columns: repeat(auto-fill, minmax(180px, 1fr)) — grid template for portfolio layout

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: #31135D on #ffffff = 13.6:1 (AAA). #6b7280 on #ffffff = 4.6:1 (AA). Status indicators use color + icon (not color alone) for accessibility.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Portfolio total income (summary row) > Individual unit income > Unit metadata (name, occupancy). The summary row uses the hero typography pattern from looks-001. Individual unit cards use a reduced but still prominent typography for income. The visual flow is: total → individual → detail, matching the professional host's assessment order.
elements.brand_alignment: The compact grid pattern aligns with the Style Guide's 'clean, modern' aesthetic while serving professional users. The density is appropriate for portfolio management tools (not consumer marketplaces), reinforcing the 'professional host tool' positioning that differentiates from Airbnb.

elements.title: Guest Trust Profile Visual: Employment-First Card Layout
elements.problem: When Tammy opens a proposal, her System 1 needs to quickly assess 'Is this guest trustworthy?' before engaging System 2 for financial evaluation. The current proposal view likely presents booking data (dates, rates) with guest identity as secondary. Visually, this means the host's eye lands on transactional data first, with no trust-positive visual anchor. Kahneman's availability heuristic fills the trust vacuum with the host's most vivid negative experiences. The visual pattern must place trust-building data (employer, purpose, origin) in the position where the eye naturally lands first — the top-left of the card, in the largest typography, with visual weight that signals 'read this first.'
elements.solution: Design a Guest Trust Profile card that occupies the top of every proposal view. The card should use a two-column layout: LEFT column (40%) shows guest avatar (--avatar-md, 48px) with name below, a verification badge icon, and origin city in --text-gray. RIGHT column (60%) shows employer name in Inter Semibold 600 at 16px, role/title in Inter Regular 400 at 14px, purpose of stay in Inter Regular 400 at 14px in --text-description, and payment status as a pill badge. The employer name should be the most prominent text element in the card (after the guest's name), using --primary-purple to signal data confidence. A subtle divider (--border-color) separates the trust profile from booking details below. The visual order (name → employer → purpose → origin → payment) mirrors Tammy's evaluation checklist exactly.

evidence.quote: If they're a nurse and they're going to be working at a particular hospital, I know where they're working.
evidence.insight: Employer information is her primary trust signal. It must be visually prominent — not hidden behind a profile expansion or a 'view details' click.

evidence.quote: Personal experiences, pictures, and vivid examples are more available than incidents that happened to others, or mere words, or statistics.
evidence.insight: A guest photo + employer name + purpose creates a 'vivid example' that counters negative availability. Abstract verification badges are 'mere words.' Specific employment data is a 'personal experience' surrogate.

typography: Inter Bold 700 at 18px (--text-lg) for guest name
Inter Semibold 600 at 16px (--text-md) for employer name
Inter Regular 400 at 14px (--text-base) for role, purpose, origin

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: All text colors on rgb(252, 250, 255) background exceed 4.5:1 ratio. #31135D on off-white = ~13:1 (AAA). #374151 on off-white = ~7.5:1 (AAA).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Guest name (largest) > Employer name (second largest, in brand purple) > Role/Purpose (standard body) > Origin/Payment status (smallest). The employer name in --primary-purple creates a visual anchor that draws the eye to the most decision-relevant data point.
elements.brand_alignment: Using the brand purple for employer data signals that the platform has verified and elevated this information. The purple-tinted card background (--bg-off-white) maintains the trust card visual family from looks-002, creating consistency across all trust-related displays.

elements.title: Seasonal Income Visualization: Vacancy-to-Earnings Color Gradient
elements.problem: Tammy has predictable seasonal patterns: busy November-December, vacant January-April, variable rest of year. The platform needs to visually communicate how Split Lease fills her vacancy periods without requiring her to interpret a complex data table. Kahneman's availability heuristic means that her most vivid financial memory is 'empty units in January' — this negative availability must be countered with an equally vivid visual representation of 'Split Lease fills January.' A static number or text explanation is less available (less memorable, less emotionally impactful) than a visual pattern showing the transformation from vacancy to income.
elements.solution: Design a 12-month timeline visualization where each month is a block colored by income level relative to the host's monthly anchor. Months at or above anchor ($5,000) are filled with --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)). Months below anchor but earning (e.g., vacancy-season Split Lease income at $2,500-$3,500) use a lighter purple (--accent-purple, rgb(140, 104, 238)). Vacant months with no income use --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6). The visualization should show two rows: TOP ROW = 'Without Split Lease' (showing current seasonal pattern with gray vacancy months), BOTTOM ROW = 'With Split Lease' (showing vacancy months filled with light purple). The visual contrast between 'gray gap' and 'purple fill' makes the value proposition visceral and instantly available to System 1. Monthly income numbers appear below each block in Inter Medium 500 at 12px.

evidence.quote: From after Christmas to March, April, we were pretty much empty.
evidence.insight: The vacancy window is concrete and predictable. A visual representation of 'these months are empty' → 'these months are filled' is more persuasive than a textual explanation.

evidence.quote: Right around January, I know I have vacancies.
evidence.insight: She knows exactly when her vacancies occur. The visualization validates her knowledge while showing the platform's solution.

evidence.quote: Dramatic events temporarily increase the availability of their category.
evidence.insight: The visual transformation from 'gray vacancy' to 'purple income' is a dramatic visual event that increases the availability of 'Split Lease fills vacancies' in the host's memory. This availability effect persists after the host leaves the page.

colors: --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for months at or above anchor
--accent-purple (rgb(140, 104, 238)) for months below anchor but earning
typography: Inter Medium 500 at 11px (--text-xs) for month abbreviations
Inter Medium 500 at 12px (--text-sm) for income numbers below blocks
Inter Semibold 600 at 14px (--text-base) for row labels ('Without Split Lease' / 'With Split Lease')
new_tokens_needed: --color-income-above-anchor: rgb(109, 49, 194) — semantic token for months meeting anchor
--color-income-below-anchor: rgb(140, 104, 238) — semantic token for months with partial income

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: Month labels (#31135D) on white background = 13.6:1 (AAA). Income numbers use --text-dark on white for readability. Color blocks are decorative and supplemented by income numbers below for accessibility.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The visual weight of the color contrast (gray vs. purple) conveys the value proposition before any numbers are read. The before/after row comparison creates immediate visual comprehension: 'gray months become purple months.' Numbers are secondary to the color pattern.
elements.brand_alignment: The purple gradient from vacant (gray) to fully earning (deep purple) aligns with the brand's purple identity while adding semantic meaning. The lighter purple for partial income creates a natural 'more purple = more income' visual language that extends the brand palette functionally.
